Main objectives: To engage workers in change processes, create a common language, discuss existing reality, investigate future visions and make requirement specifications on aspects of work organisation, technology and education. The guiding principles: Games should be easy to work with, cheap to produce and play, flexible and facilitate the testing of several alternatives. The games should be relevant in the actual work context and support discussions of existing as well as future work and technology.

Examples of Operational Rule s Highly structured versus loosely structured. Everyone pick five images they find interesting The first design move is to choose between the three game boards. Each player takes turn making design move s . The participants make design moves by placing game pieces on a game board. Each placing of game pieces are negotiated with the other players before placed on the game board What game pieces to make moves with is decided by chance versus decided by the players interests.

body.outsider: By Eva Brandt, The Danish Design School

Examples of Behavioral Rules Highly structured versus loosely structured. No critique – but try to understand the other players point of view. Not about winning or loosing but co-creation through playful experimentation. Maximum time for speaking is one minute, then game pieces have to be moved before talking again. Play oneself versus play a role for instance in accordance with a role script. Act/react to the other participants and design moves in accordance with your role description.

Examples of rules about the responsibility of the facilitator Create an dynamic and informal atmosphere. Introduces the game and the rules of the game. Make sure that each player has an equal chance to speak. Take part in game playing versus not take part in game playing. Make sure to have time in the program for presentations by each group when playing in parallel. Be neutral versus having for instance design ideas and preferences, which becomes part of the inquiries. The facilitator is the timekeeper.
Exploratory design games is a valuable framework in co-design
The framework is flexible and can include design projects within various design fields

N ot one specific and generic game, which fit all kinds of projects, but that games are designed for various purposes and with different means. Suggests series of collaborative events each organised in a game format with focus on staging, evoking and enacting. The outcome of each event is a tangible artefact that help creating continuity. The game part: both how participation is staged and the atmosphere and attitude within which the game playing takes place. Engaging and fun. Informal atmosphere, which is the most productive in creative work.

G ame rules and tangible game pieces support different participants in making design moves. Game materials: create a common ground that everybody can relate to. Game materials: becomes ’things-to-think- with’. Game pieces: becomes an inherent part of the language and hereby the argumentation. Images and video snippets from field studies provide a deeper knowledge of users and use situations, which the designers remember.
To use open-ended fragments or questions seems to allow for many different interpretations leading to a more open and creative dialogue.
Design games based on chance focus on how to get out of the habit and experiencing new.
Stylised game materials seem to elucidate the participants intentions and interests, as they are not implicit in the materials provided.
Game rules like turn taking help levelling of the stakeholders.
